meta.title: Introduction To Data Structure
meta.path: quizzes/Computer Science/2/2/Data Structures and Algorithms/Introduction to Data Structure.json

questions.explanation: Data structures (like Arrays) help us store data so we can use it efficiently.
options: The way data is organized in a computer's memory
The physical metal inside a CPU

questions.explanation: An algorithm is like a recipe for a computer to follow.
options: A step-by-step procedure to solve a problem
The name of a software company

questions.q: Which data structure is like a 'stack' of plates (last one in is the first one out)?
questions.explanation: A Stack follows the LIFO (Last-In, First-Out) principle.

questions.q: If you want to find a name in a sorted phonebook, which method is faster?
questions.explanation: Binary search is much faster for sorted data than a linear search.
options: Checking every page one by one
Binary Search (splitting the book in half repeatedly)

questions.explanation: Arrays are the most basic way to store a list of items of the same type.
options: A collection of items stored at contiguous memory locations

questions.q: True or False: A good algorithm should be fast and use as little memory as possible.
questions.explanation: Efficiency in time and space is the goal of every programmer.

questions.q: True or False: You can only have one 'correct' algorithm for a single problem.
questions.explanation: Many different algorithms can solve the same problem; some are just faster than others.

questions.q: True or False: A 'Queue' data structure is like a line at a grocery store (first in, first out).
questions.explanation: Queues follow the FIFO (First-In, First-Out) principle.

questions.q: True or False: Sorting an array means putting the elements in a specific order (like A to Z).
questions.explanation: Sorting is one of the most fundamental tasks in computer science.

questions.q: True or False: Data structures have nothing to do with how fast a program runs.
questions.explanation: Choosing the wrong data structure can make a program very slow.

questions.q: What is the difference between a Data Structure and an Algorithm?
questions.answer: A data structure is a way to store data, while an algorithm is the set of steps used to process or manipulate that data.

questions.q: Give an example of an algorithm you use in real life.
questions.answer: Following a recipe to bake a cake or following directions on a map to reach a destination.
